hotspots.hotspot:
Expansion

An expansion is a period of economic growth, so GDP is rising. During an expansion, a nation has low unemployment and increasing income.

Peak

A peak is the temporary high point in economic growth. At the peak, the economy has full employment, meaning there is no cyclical unemployment and most job-seekers can find jobs. Growth has stopped, however.

Recession

A contraction occurs when GDP is decreasing. In this phase, unemployment is increasing. Businesses lay off workers because consumers aren't buying as many goods and services. If a contraction lasts longer than two consecutive quarters, it is called a recession.

Trough

A trough occurs when GDP hits a temporary low point. Although unemployment is high, the economy is poised for a turnaround.

Between 2001 and 2008, the U.S. was experiencing an economic expansion. That means the GDP was growing each year, and American incomes were increasing. This was caused by the boom in new technology, especially increased access to cell phones and the Internet, which made businesses more efficient.
In the 2nd quarter of 2008, between April and June, the GDP hit a high point, called a peak. The long period of growth came to a halt, mostly because of the housing and banking crisis.

Between 2008 and mid-2009, the U.S. GDP dropped for four straight quarters. This is called a contraction or a recession. Business investment and consumer spending both decreased, due to the banking crisis and the drop in housing prices.

According to this graph, the U.S. GDP hit a low point or trough in the second quarter of 2009. The economy began to turn around, partly because of government stabilization policies and partly due to improved efficiency in business firms.
In this period, the GDP is growing, but it is still not back to the previous high. This is called a recovery. Government policies and improved consumption helped the recovery along.

Here you can see that the GDP in the second quarter of 2010 surpasses the previous peak. At this point, the economy is beginning another expansion. The economy is growing, mostly due to increased efficiency, although many Americans still felt that there was a recession.
